title: What are the disadvantages of aloe vera?
text:
The Dark Side of the Succulent: What are the Disadvantages of Aloe Vera? Aloe vera, that spiky succulent perched on windowsills and touted as a natural remedy for everything from sunburn to digestive woes, certainly has a compelling PR campaign. But before you slather it on every inch of your being or start guzzling aloe juice by the gallon, let’s pull back the curtain and examine the potential downsides of this seemingly miraculous plant. While aloe vera offers a host of benefits, like any other substance, it’s not without its drawbacks. The main disadvantages of aloe vera stem from potential allergic reactions , digestive upset from internal use (particularly aloe latex), drug interactions , and the risk of serious health problems with prolonged or excessive use, including kidney damage and liver issues . It is also important to note that aloe latex might have the potential to cause cancer.
Understanding the Different Forms of Aloe Before we dive deeper, it’s crucial to understand the two main forms of aloe vera used:
Aloe Gel: This is the clear, jelly-like substance found in the inner leaf. It’s primarily used topically for its soothing and moisturizing properties. Aloe Latex: This is the yellow, bitter liquid found just under the plant’s skin. It contains anthraquinones , potent compounds that act as a strong laxative. Most disadvantages are related to aloe latex use. Disadvantages of Topical Aloe Vera While generally safe for topical use, aloe vera isn’t without its potential problems:
Allergic Reactions: Some individuals are allergic to aloe vera. People who are allergic to garlic, onions, or tulips are more likely to react. Symptoms can include itching, redness, hives, or even contact dermatitis . Always perform a patch test on a small area of skin before applying aloe vera extensively. Skin Sensitivity: While aloe vera is known for soothing skin, it can actually cause dryness or irritation in some people, particularly those with sensitive skin . Ironically, it can even lead to pimples if it dries out the skin too much. Burning Sensation: If you experience a burning sensation after applying aloe vera, especially if it’s a commercial product, it could be due to preservatives or other ingredients in the gel. It might also indicate that aloe vera simply doesn’t agree with your skin. Dehydrating Effect: Aloe vera has a cooling effect, but in some instances, can lead to dehydration of the skin and lead to pimples appearing due to the dehydrating effect. Its better to stop Aloe vera gel and consider alternative moisturizer in its place. Disadvantages of Oral Aloe Vera This is where the potential for significant side effects increases:
Digestive Distress: The aloe latex , present in whole-leaf extracts and some aloe vera juices, is a powerful laxative. It can cause severe abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and electrolyte imbalances , especially with prolonged use. Drug Interactions: Aloe vera can interfere with the absorption of certain medications. Specifically, it can lower blood potassium levels , which can be dangerous for people taking heart medications or diuretics. It can also interact with diabetes medications, potentially causing dangerously low blood sugar levels . Kidney Damage: Long-term use of aloe latex in high doses (even as little as 1 gram per day) has been linked to acute kidney failure . The anthraquinones in aloe latex can damage kidney cells. Heart Problems: Chronic hypokalemia (low potassium) caused by aloe latex abuse can lead to heart arrhythmias and other serious cardiac issues. Liver Toxicity: While less common, prolonged use of aloe vera supplements has been associated with drug-induced hepatitis and other forms of liver toxicity. Pseudomelanosis Coli: Long-term use of aloe latex can cause pseudomelanosis coli , a darkening of the colon lining. While often asymptomatic, its long-term implications are not fully understood. Potential Carcinogen: Some studies have suggested a potential link between aloe latex and cancer, particularly colon cancer. While more research is needed, it’s a serious concern to consider. Not Recommended for Children: Oral use of aloe latex and whole-leaf extract is generally not recommended for children under 12 due to the risk of digestive upset and other side effects. Impact on Blood Pressure: Aloe Vera Gel Powder May Help Lower Blood Pressure; therefore, it might offer some benefit as a complementary therapy, but research is still very limited. Who Should Avoid Aloe Vera? Certain individuals should exercise extreme caution or completely avoid using aloe vera, especially orally:
People with Allergies: Those allergic to plants in the Liliaceae family (garlic, onions, tulips, etc.) may be allergic to aloe vera. People with Intestinal Problems: If you have intestinal problems, such as Crohn’s disease, ulcerative colitis, or irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) , avoid oral aloe vera, as it can exacerbate your symptoms. People with Heart Disease: Oral aloe vera can interfere with heart medications and worsen electrolyte imbalances, which can be dangerous for people with heart conditions. People with Hemorrhoids: The laxative effect of aloe latex can irritate hemorrhoids. People with Kidney Problems: Aloe vera can worsen kidney problems, especially with long-term use of aloe latex. People with Diabetes: Aloe vera can lower blood sugar levels, potentially causing hypoglycemia in people with diabetes who are taking medication to lower their blood sugar. People with Electrolyte Imbalances: Aloe vera can disrupt electrolyte balance, particularly potassium levels. Pregnant and Breastfeeding Women: The safety of oral aloe vera during pregnancy and breastfeeding hasn’t been established, so it’s best to avoid it. Responsible Aloe Vera Use If you choose to use aloe vera, follow these guidelines:
Choose Reputable Products: Opt for aloe vera products from reputable brands that clearly state the ingredients and processing methods. Read Labels Carefully: Pay attention to the ingredients list and avoid products that contain aloe latex if you’re using it topically or if you’re concerned about its laxative effects. Start Small: When trying a new aloe vera product, start with a small amount to see how your skin or body reacts. Monitor for Side Effects: Be aware of potential side effects and discontinue use if you experience any adverse reactions. Consult Your Doctor: Talk to your doctor before using aloe vera, especially if you have any underlying health conditions or are taking medications. Aloe vera can be a beneficial plant, but it’s crucial to be aware of its potential downsides. By understanding the risks and using aloe vera responsibly, you can minimize the chances of experiencing adverse effects. Remember, natural doesn’t always mean safe, and moderation is key.
You can find further information on environmental health and other related topics on enviroliteracy.org , the website of The Environmental Literacy Council .
Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) Here are some common questions about the disadvantages of aloe vera:
1. Can aloe vera cause diarrhea? Yes, aloe latex is a potent laxative and can cause diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and dehydration.
2. Is it safe to use aloe vera on my face every day? While some find it beneficial, daily use can lead to dryness or irritation for some individuals. Monitor your skin for any adverse reactions.
3. Can aloe vera interact with medications? Yes, aloe vera can interact with several medications, including heart medications, diuretics, and diabetes medications. Consult your doctor if you’re taking any medications.
4. Does aloe vera have any effect on blood sugar levels? Yes, aloe vera can lower blood sugar levels. People with diabetes should be cautious and monitor their blood sugar closely.
5. Can aloe vera cause kidney damage? Long-term use of aloe latex in high doses has been linked to kidney damage and acute kidney failure.
6. Is aloe vera safe for pregnant women? The safety of oral aloe vera during pregnancy hasn’t been established, so it’s best to avoid it.
7. Can I use aloe vera on my private parts? While some find it soothing, it’s best to exercise caution, especially with concentrated forms. It can cause allergic contact dermatitis, leading to rashes, itching, and burning sensations.
8. Why does my face feel like it’s burning after applying aloe vera gel? This could be due to preservatives or other ingredients in the gel, or it could indicate that aloe vera simply doesn’t suit your skin.
9. Can aloe vera remove dark spots? Aloe vera may help fade dark spots caused by acne or pimples due to its anti-inflammatory and skin-regenerating properties.
10. What are the long-term side effects of aloe vera? Long-term use of aloe latex can lead to kidney damage, heart problems, liver toxicity, and pseudomelanosis coli.
11. Is it okay to leave aloe vera on my skin overnight? Leaving pure aloe vera gel on for too long can lead to potential irritation and dryness. It is best to leave it on for a little while — approximately five to 10 minutes — and then rinse.
12. Can aloe vera cause tiny bumps on my skin? Yes, aloe vera can make sensitive skin dry up and can lead to pimples appearing due to the dehydrating effect.
13. Is aloe vera good for gut health? Aloe vera juice has significant cooling effects, and it decreases gut and stomach inflammation. In addition to these benefits, aloe vera juice helps in treating many problems related to acidity.
14. Does aloe vera tighten skin? Aloe vera helps to naturally increase the production of collagen – one of those all important proteins that gives your skin its youthful firmness while its astringent properties constrict blood vessels and flow to the skin which give it a tightening effect on the body and face.
15. Can aloe latex increase the risk of cancer? Some studies have suggested a potential link between aloe latex and cancer. While more research is needed, it’s a serious concern to consider.
